                                                    Politico
Marc Caputo's must-read briefing on what's hot, crazy or shady about politics in the Sunshine State
08/31/15, 06:10 AM EDT
By Marc Caputo (mcaputo@politico.com; @MarcACaputo) with Kristen East (keast@politico.com; @kristenicoleast)
Happy Monday, Florida. And goodbye Tropical Storm Erika (for now at least). Though the storm did little to South Florida, Dominica needs help. It’s a busy political week in South Florida: Jeb Bush has a Monday Coral Gables fundraiser and a Tuesday school visit in Miami; Ted Cruz has a Tuesday Bal Harbor fundraiser (his first in Florida) on Wednesday; Vice President Joe Biden headlines a Senate Democratic fundraiser in Miami on Tuesday and then holds two events in South Florida on Wednesday, including a trip for Debbie Wasserman Schultz to pitch the president’s Iran-nuke deal.
DWS PR FAIL – “Wasserman Schultz caught up in Iran-deal controversy,” by POLITICO’s Marc Caputo: A new Democratic controversy has erupted over President Obama’s nuclear Iran deal, and once again Democratic National Committee Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz is in the middle of it. On Saturday at the DNC’s summer meeting, Wasserman Schultz made a procedural ruling against a show of support for the president’s signature foreign-policy initiative– a decision she and her press shop have refused to explain openly. 
Some Democrats, already upset that the South Florida representative hasn’t said if she’ll back the Iran deal in Congress, began trashing her and even calling for her ouster as DNC chair. The problem with the accusations from her fellow Democrats: they’re not really accurate, according to those who spoke on the record about what happened Saturday. http://politi.co/1NR6UBhAnd as Wasserman Schultz stayed silent, the bad headlines poured in:
“Dems say party chair blocked Iran resolution at DNC meeting,” The Washington Post first reported. http://wapo.st/1ItvaCl
“Wasserman Schultz blocked Iran resolution at DNC meeting: report,” The Hill followed.
“‘Dump Debbie’: Dems are livid with Wasserman Schultz over blocking Iran deal resolution, lack of debates,” the conservative Twitter aggregation website, Twitchy, wrote. http://bit.ly/1JqIHfI
DWS PRIMARY? – Miami-Dade School Board Member Martin Karp, a Democrat and Wasserman Schultz constituent, is sending out mailers to organize people to rally against the Iran deal at her office. Asked if he’d challenge Wasserman Schultz in a Democratic primary for opposing the deal, he said, "That’s not my intention. ... My only interest at this time is to get her to make a decision as soon as possible.” Well, that’s not a no. The front and back of the mailers are here http://bit.ly/1Q2rzkR and here http://bit.ly/1NR7uih. Hat tip to Aron Goldman for posting the above images on Twitter.
--Aron Goldman @ArgoJournal: “Received this mailer for a rally tomorrow in front of DWS’s office in Aventura: http://bit.ly/1O2uTv2”
PICKING UP STEAM – “Remove Debbie Wasserman Schultz as DNC Chair,” MoveOn.Org petition: http://bit.ly/1NQMHvm
JOYOUS AG -- @PamBondi: “Can’t wait to hear the great Rick Springfield tonight!!! #RickSpringfield.” http://bit.ly/1Jv8Qw8
NOT JOYOUS -- “Top Jeb fundraisers leave campaign amid troubling signs,” by POLITICO’s Alex Isenstadt and Marc Caputo: “Three top Jeb Bush fundraisers abruptly parted ways with his presidential campaign on Friday, amid internal personality conflicts and questions about the strength of his candidacy, POLITICO has learned. There are different versions of what transpired. The Florida-based fundraising consultants — Kris Money, Trey McCarley and Debbie Aleksander — have said that they voluntarily quit the campaign and were still working with Bush's super PAC, Right to Rise Super PAC. Others said the three, who worked under the same contract, were let go because they were no longer needed for the current phase of the campaign. None of the three responded to requests for comment. Bush spokesman Tim Miller would only say that “Governor Bush has the widest and deepest fundraising operation of any candidate in the field. Ann Herberger — a longtime aide with more than two decades of experience in state and national politics — will continue to lead the operation in Florida with our team in Miami.” http://politi.co/1PEucc2
 JEB’S MISCALCULATION? The departures and news of cutbacks raise a question that we can’t yet answer: Did Jeb’s clever campaign strategy of delaying his official candidacy announcement -- to raise unlimited money form top-dollar donors for the super PAC -- backfire? Because raising super PAC money is more difficult as an announced candidate, Jeb made his candidacy official June 15, late in the game because it left only a few weeks to raise hard money for his campaign. And he did a great job: $11.4 million in just 16 days. At the same time, Bush hired as many top-level staffers as possible to make sure he had the best he could – and so that his opponents couldn’t. That costs money that only hard-dollar donations pay for. So, relative to his campaign staff (by far the largest in the GOP field), was his fundraising too little? Is Jeb’s burn rate too high, prompting the recalculations, resizing of the campaign? The campaign says no, and that it’ll have plenty of money, etc. So we’ll have to see at the end of the quarter. Meantime, Bush and the family have a grueling fundraising schedule.
BUSH FUNDRAISING LIST: Southampton, NY (Sept. 28); Sagaponack & Quogue, NY (Sept. 29); Wilmington, NC (Saturday); Boston (Weds); President George W. Bush Lunch, New York City (Thurs); NYC fundraiser with Jets owner Woody Johnson (Sept. 8); Seattle (Sept. 14); Luncheon with Mrs. Columba Bush and Jeb Bush, Jr. Los Angeles (Sept. 15); Portland, OR (Sept. 15); Bakersfield, California (Sept. 17); Technology Roundtable with Jeb Bush, Jr. Silicon Valley (Sept. 17); Young Professionals with Jeb Bush, Jr, San Francisco (Sept. 17); San Francisco (Sept. 17); Las Vegas, NV (Sept. 17); Athens, GA (Sept. 19); Washington D.C. (Sept. 24); Evening Reception with President George W. Bush Tyler, TX (Sept. 24); Young Professionals with Jeb Bush, Jr. Miami (Sept. 24); Boca Raton (Sept. 25); Jeb Bush, Jr. Gainesville, FL (Sept. 26); St. Louis, MO (Sept. 28) Oklahoma City (Sept. 29)
--Jeb Bush fundraiser Monday in Coral Gables,” by Saintpeters Blog’s Peter Schorsch: http://bit.ly/1JFen4u
ONE-WAY JEB -- “Jeb Bush touts consensus-builder style, but many point to discordant Florida record,” by The Tampa Bay Times’ Adam C. Smith: “His style is my way or the highway,” said former Florida House Speaker Johnnie Byrd, a Republican who supported most of Bush's agenda but is undecided for 2016. “The whole time I worked with him, he never listened to me or anybody else in the process. If Mitch McConnell and John Boehner think they're going to have a great relationship with President Jeb Bush, they better watch out.” http://bit.ly/1Q1MKDO
LBA V. TRUMP -- “Latino business group denounces ‘ignorant’ Trump campaign, cancels contract,” by POLITICO’s Marc Caputo: “In a stinging denunciation of Donald Trump, the nation’s largest Hispanic construction trade group, the Latin Builders Association, announced Friday that it would cancel its gala at his resort in Doral due to his “recent pattern of bigoted, sexist and ignorant verbal assaults on immigrants, women and veterans.” The Miami-based LBA made the announcement after the 650-member association’s executive board made the decision to “rescind” a contract to hold its annual gala Nov. 14 at the Trump National Doral Miami. The letter was released at the LBA’s monthly luncheon to explain to members that the group is seeking a new venue. A spokeswoman for Trump, first approached for comment Thursday by phone and email, still could not be reached. The LBA’s decision could prompt a lawsuit, but the nonprofit’s board made clear it was willing to risk that fight.” http://politi.co/1fNqWP8
O’CONNELL CALLS IT QUITS -- “Florida lottery secretary steps down after travel report," by POLITICO’s Matt Dixon and Jessica Bakeman: Florida Lottery Secretary Cynthia O’Connell is stepping down in the wake of a POLITICO Florida report that she took nine weeks of vacation and racked up nearly $30,000 in travel bills last year while her agency was struggling with a fund scandal and audit. Her resignation takes effect Oct. 1. She will leave to pursue opportunities in the private sector.
“Cynthia has been part of my team since my first year in office and she has done a tremendous job serving Florida families,” Gov. Rick Scott said in a statement announcing the resignation. He did not ask her to resign, his office said. http://politi.co/1NI5ERM
TESTING TURMOIL – “Seminole County furthers push to replace state exams with national alternatives,” by POLITICO’s Jessica Bakeman: "National tests like the SAT are closely enough aligned to Florida’s academic standards to replace the state’s own exams, the leaders of a high-performing school district neighboring Orlando argued in a recent letter to state education officials. Seminole County Public Schools leaders last week renewed their push for the state to ditch the Florida Standards Assessments, computer-based exams offered for the first time this spring. The leaders want to replace the state’s tests with the Iowa Test of Basic Skills, the PSAT and the SAT, respectively at appropriate grade levels. Since the district leaders first proposed the plan in July, they’ve rebranded their idea, originally dubbed the ‘Seminole Solution,’ as the ‘Sunshine Solution,’ hoping to reflect growing support from other school districts statewide. Key state lawmakers have also expressed support for the plan, as POLITICO Florida first reported. Their letter comes just days before the state is expected to receive the results of a third-party study of the validity of Florida’s state exams, which came into question after technical problems plagued their administration earlier this year.” http://politi.co/1Euc9Vu
COUP, ME? -- “Ingoglia: ‘I am not running for speaker’,” by POLITICO’s Matt Dixon: Republican Party of Florida chairman Blaise Ingoglia said Saturday that he will not actively seek the post of House speaker, and will remove himself from a reform push being considered by that chamber’s G.O.P. members. “I am not going to offer myself as a candidate for speaker of the House,” Ingoglia told the state GOP board at its quarterly meeting. “I am not running for speaker.” Ingoglia, also a state representative from Spring Hill, was one of the faces of a reform effort organized by lawmakers who say they want to change the way House speakers are selected. That movement has stirred anxiety among supporters of state Rep. Eric Eisnaugle, an Orlando Republican whose speaker bid at one point had the backing of nearly the entire 19-member freshman class. http://politi.co/1NQrotW
SMOKIN JOE OLIVA -- “The swift and firm-footed rise of Miami’s Speaker-D Jose Oliva,” by Miami Herald’s Mary Ellen Klas: “Rep. Jose Oliva kept an icy cool as he verbally sparred with his Senate counterpart Bill Galvano over the redistricting map that would force the Legislature’s special session to end in stalemate. As the meeting adjourned Oliva, a Miami Lakes Republican, suggested they might do better to take the meeting to his house, where they could light up a cigar. ‘As long as they are Oliva cigars,’ mused Galvano, R-Bradenton, a reference to the Nicaraguan tobacco cultivated and sold by Oliva’s family.” http://bit.ly/1JuGhPs
SMACK ATTACK -- “To combat overdose epidemic, Manatee officials call for increased use of ‘heroin antidote’,” by Bradenton Herald’s Kate Irby: “Dr. Mark Sylvester can’t count the number of patients he's lost to heroin overdoses in the past year. One patient was 16 years old. After five years of working with addictions as a psychiatrist, Sylvester knows how complicated treatment can be. Saving addicts from dying of an overdose can be extremely simple by comparison, requiring only a quickly administered heroin antidote of naloxone, or Narcan. ... The Florida Legislature made access to those overdose extinguishers much easier during the 2015 session. Gov. Rick Scott signed a bill into law in June allowing doctors to prescribe naloxone to third parties such as family members and friends of addicts. That way, if someone is concerned about someone they know overdosing on heroin, they can have it on hand if an overdose occurs.” http://bit.ly/1KVDvAK
REMEMBERING STEVEN SOTLOFF -- “Steven Sotloff’s parents open up as 1-yr anniversary nears,” by AP: “South Florida residents Shirley and Arthur Sotloff have spoken little since the Islamic State group released a video showing a jihadi behead American-Israeli journalist Steven Sotloff on September 2, 2014.” http://apne.ws/1KVDIUw
DEMS PLAY TRUMP CARD -- “Democrats Alan Grayson, Patrick Murphy play the Donald Trump card in Senate primary,” by Palm Beach Post’s George Bennett: http://pbpo.st/1O1VGaT
--“Joan Jett and the Wall Streeters pony up for Wall Street-bashing Alan Grayson,” by The Tampa Bay Times’ Adam C. Smith: http://bit.ly/1Euv9TT
HAHAHAHAHAHA! US REP BASHES FL ‘DYSFUNCTION’ -- “Buchanan discouraged by dysfunction,” by The Sarasota Herald Tribune’s Zac Anderson: “U.S. Rep. Vern Buchanan is familiar with dysfunctional governing bodies. Congress has a 19 percent approval rating and Buchanan believes that the dysfunctional tag is well earned ‘in a lot of aspects … But when you look at the state, they’ve always seemed like they’ve been better about resolving these issues,’ said the Longboat Key Republican. The latest legislative meltdown over congressional redistricting has Buchanan questioning that assessment of the GOP-controlled Legislature, though, and fuming over the uncertainty that continues to surround his congressional district.” http://bit.ly/1Kmyoiv
NELSON: BIDEN WON’T RUN -- “Bill Nelson on Hillary Clinton emails, Joe Biden, Rick Scott, Iran nukes,” by Palm Beach Post’s George Bennett: “Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson believes Hillary Clinton‘s explanations for using a homebrew email server as secretary of state but is ‘concerned’ with the way her campaign has handled the issue. Speaking to a Forum Club of the Palm Beaches lunch today, Nelson predicted that Clinton will ‘overcome’ the email questions and that Vice President Joe Biden will not enter the presidential race. Nelson also shrugged off the possibility of Republican Gov. Rick Scott challenging him for Senate in 2018 and defended President Barack Obama‘s nuclear deal with Iran.” http://pbpo.st/1Eu0E0g
FL’S INVESTMENTS OK -- “Florida’s financial outlook is strong,” by Herald Tribune’s Lloyd Dunkelberger: “A little volatility in the stock market may have unnerved many Floridians as they watched their retirement accounts rise and fall with the recent abrupt moves in the financial markets. But the market volatility didn’t seem to faze Ben Watkins, one of the state’s key financial managers. ... Watkins told the aides in preparation for next week’s Cabinet meeting in St. Augustine that the state government’s financial well-being is strong.” http://bit.ly/1NQsQMG
LAND WARS -- “Environmental groups sue Legislature over Amendment 1 spending,” by POLITICO’s Marc Caputo: “A coalition of environmental groups sued the state of Florida on Friday and asked a judge to stop what they claim is unlawful spending of state conservation money.” http://politi.co/1X2FhsL
WEST NILE WARNING -- “Pinellas records first human case of West Nile Virus in 2015,” by The Tampa Bay Times’ staff: “A 32-year-old man in Pinellas County recently tested positive for West Nile Virus, the first confirmed human case of the mosquito-borne illness this year, according to local health officials. To date, county analysts have recorded 23 positive tests for West Nile in sentinel chickens, which serve as a first line of defense to determine the prevalence of the virus in Tampa Bay. According to the Florida Department of Health, many people do not show symptoms of West Nile Virus when infected. Those who do experience ill effects typically suffer from headache, pain and fatigue as a result of West Nile Fever.” http://bit.ly/1IpUbOW
FL SENATE WARS -- “Republicans: Latvala courting Dems in bid for Senate presidency,” by POLITICO’s Matt Dixon: As the ongoing battle to become the next state Senate president approaches its third legislative session, a handful of Republicans say fellow GOP Sen. Jack Latvala is courting Democrats in a “desperate” attempt to win the race. “I think he is throwing a Hail Mary,” said Sen. Jeff Brandes, a St. Petersburg Republican who has quarreled politically with Latvala in the past and could run against him in the future. Brandes, like other senators who say Latvala is wooing Democrats, supports Joe Negron, a Stuart Republican who has been fighting with Latvala for nearly three years over the Senate president's term that begins in 2017. The fight changed on Wednesday, however, when Negron proclaimed he had the support of 14 of the chamber’s 26 Republicans. As a result, Senate President Andy Gardiner of Orlando called for a Republican designation vote in December, which could effectively end the battle. http://politi.co/1PYs0ge
ERIKA’S WAKE -- “Dominica digs out from storm damage that killed at least 20,” by AP’s Carlisle Jno Baptiste and Danico Coto: “Rescue crews jumped off boats and trudged through mud, rocks and uprooted trees Saturday to reach communities cut off by a tropical storm that killed at least 20 people and left nearly 50 missing in the eastern Caribbean island of Dominica. Volunteers helped carry food, water and clothes for dozens of Dominicans who have been isolated for up to three days after Tropical Storm Erika dumped some 15 inches (38 centimeters) of rain on the mountainous island. Prime Minister Roosevelt Skerrit pleaded for international aid, saying the damage pushed Dominica back by two decades, and he warned of more rain in upcoming days. He met Saturday with members of a newly created committee charged with helping rebuild an island devastated by floods and landslides.” http://apne.ws/1Eu1kmp
SHOULDA PREDICTED THIS – “Psychic Readers Network sues General Mills over Miss Cleo,” by AP: “The South Florida company that owns the rights to the popular TV psychic ‘Miss Cleo’ is suing General Mills alleging copyright infringement for hiring the psychic to promote its breakfast cereal. According to a complaint recently filed in federal court, Psychic Readers Network, Inc. said General Mills disregarded the intellectual property rights of others with a series of online ads where Miss Cleo amazes callers with her confident prediction that they will be filling their bowls with French Toast Crunch. The cereal was discontinued in 2006 but made a comeback earlier this year with help of Miss Cleo, and a Facebook fan page. The lawsuit alleges the videos look very similar to the Psychic Readers Network's commercials featuring Miss Cleo from the early 2000s. The Psychic Readers Network said it has spent more than $100 million to promote Miss Cleo since hiring her in the late 1990s and making her the company spokesperson. Psychic Readers Network said it copyrighted Miss Cleo Creatives in 2002, according to the lawsuit.” http://apne.ws/1JvjqmK

                                            By 
Sam Nunn
                                             and 
Richard Lugar


                                            By 
Matt Latimer


                                            By 
Aaron MaK


                                            By 
POLITICO Magazine

 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: POLITICO Florida Playbook: Wasserman Schultz’s Iran troubles deepen; Jeb’s fundraiser woes & schedule; testing trouble; RPOF chair backtracks in coup; West Nile virus alert; when psychics sue
